critique: This document is an executive order from 1941 regarding the exportation of iron and steel. It is difficult to assess its ideological tilt as it is primarily concerned with trade regulations during a time of national defense preparation. It doesn't directly address immigration, civil liberties, or social inclusion. It expands federal control over trade, which could be seen as a form of economic intervention. The focus on national defense suggests a prioritization of national security. There is no direct impact on executive power. The document seems to centralize control over exports at the federal level.
